18:37 [narrator] Just as it was on July 13th, 1942. 1942年７月13日のこと
18:42 Hamburg Reserve Police Battalion 101 is on its way to the first execution. 第101警察予備大隊が 最初の処刑に向かうところだ
18:49 The policemen are unprepared for what awaits them. 隊員たちはまだ何も知らない

19:02 [Kühl, in German] They were taken to a forest. 〈人々は森へ運ばれ〉
19:05 Then the policemen led them into the forest one by one, 〈１人ずつ隊員により 森の奥へ連れて行かれた〉
19:11 some of them women, some of them children. 〈女性や子供たちもいた〉
19:21 So instead of depersonalizing the execution, 非人格化しないで執行した
19:25 and instead of keeping distance between the killer and the victim, 殺人者と犠牲者の距離も近い

19:33 and you kill that person at point-blank range. 至近距離で殺す
19:40 Several of the policemen reported having conversations as they walked them into the forest. 隊員の何人かは犠牲者と 話したと証言している

19:58 And he discovers he's going to kill the cinema owner where he used to go watch the movies. そのオーナーを 自分が殺すことに気がつく
20:05 And needless to say, the psychological toll of this was very great. 言うまでもなく精神的負担は 絶大だ
20:10 [in German] The victims feared for their lives and knew death was moments away. 〈犠牲者は もうすぐ死ぬことを恐れ〉
20:15 And the policemen were experiencing an emotional crisis 〈隊員は感情的な 危機に陥った〉
20:19 because they knew they were about to have to kill someone at point-blank range. 〈もうすぐ至近距離で 人を殺すのだから〉
20:45 [Browning] So, it's an extraordinarily gruesome experience. 恐ろしくむごたらしい経験だ
20:49 And that's when some of the men began to get sick, 吐き気を催す者もいた
20:52 because they're covered with brain matter and blood. 脳髄や血が飛び散るのだから
20:56 They-- They throw up, they-- they get demoralized, they can't continue. 嘔吐(おうと)して 任務が続けられなくなった
21:05 [narrator] The massacre lasts for hours. 虐殺は数時間続いた
21:07 In the end, 1,500 Jewish men, women and children lie dead in the forest. 最終的に森には1500体の 死体が横たわっていた
21:24 [Browning] When they went home that night, they were offered liquor, その晩 酒が振る舞われた
21:27 and most of them got drunk, but most of them couldn't eat. 隊員たちは酒は飲めたが
21:30 The-- The food was put out, but most of them had no appetite to eat. ほとんどは食欲がなかった
21:35 Uh, and some of them had nightmares that night. その晩 悪夢を見た者もいた
21:38 One man even, I guess, shooting his gun into the ceiling in a kind of nightmare. １人は銃を天井に向けて 発射する夢だ
21:43 And, uh, as another man told one of his-- his noncommissioned officers, 別の１人は こう下士官に話した

21:51 Uh, so there were-- こんな風に…
21:52 For some of the men, this was just an absolutely horrifying experience, 一部の隊員にとっては とにかく恐ろしい経験で
21:57 and they couldn't imagine ever doing it again. ２度目は想像もできなかった
22:01 [narrator] The regime knows what it is asking of the men. 政権も理解していた
22:05 As early as the summer of 1941, 早くも1941年の夏

22:12 for the men involved in this deed." 精神的支援について言及した

22:25 Otto Ohlendorf faced the same problems オーレンドルフも 虐殺を執行する部下に関し
22:28 with his men who took part in the massacres. オーレンドルフも 虐殺を執行する部下に関し 同じ問題を抱えていた
22:33 [in German] Otto Ohlendorf said, 〈オーレンドルフは言った〉
22:36 "My men suffered more than the victims." 〈私の部下は 犠牲者よりも苦しんだと〉
22:40 Looking at that from today's perspective, 〈現代風の考え方をすると〉
22:46 that's an absurd reinterpretation. 〈ばかげた解釈だ〉

22:58 because of the fact they had to do things that made them suffer. 〈自分たちも 苦しんでいたと〉
23:09 [Ferencz] He had Mitleid with his men if they had to, uh, do something 彼は自分の部下が つらい任務に当たることに
23:13 which would be painful for them. 同情をしていた

23:24 Save ammunition. 弾の節約だ

24:10 came from the Führer of the Reich. 〈総統が出した〉
24:13 So, in that sense, it's a policy determined by the Führer. 〈ということは 総統が決めた政策である〉
24:19 [narrator] In the spirit of Nazi propaganda, 彼はナチスの 宣伝活動にある——
24:22 Ohlendorf believes the Jews are responsible for communism in the Soviet Union, ソ連の共産主義はユダヤ人の 責任という内容を信じていた

24:37 He was raised in a nationalist family. 彼は国家主義の家庭で育った

25:42 The fall seemed to take forever. 〈長い落下のあと〉

26:17 I played dead, scared of being discovered. 〈私はおびえながら 死んだフリをしました〉

27:12 The first massacre of Jews in Jozefow ユダヤ人の 最初の虐殺の話は 戦後 警察に対する 尋問の内容を分析 ユダヤ人の 最初の虐殺の話は 戦後 警察に対する 尋問の内容を分析

28:03 [Welzer, in German] He was a popular, respected superior, and he said, 〈彼は人気のある 尊敬される上司だった〉
28:07 "If I had a choice, I wouldn't give you the order. But…" 〈“こんな任務は 本意ではないが…”〉
28:11 He was calling on them for solidarity, to support him with this task, 〈彼は任務遂行をするため 協力を求めた〉
28:16 which didn't come from him, 〈これは自分の 命令ではない〉
28:20 and asking them not to abandon him. 〈見捨てないでくれと〉
28:29 [in German] It was a combination of coercion and free will. 〈強制と自由の 組み合わせだ〉
28:33 They were told that they could refuse to do it, 〈彼らは任務から 外れることを許された〉
28:37 but that they would have to accept their comrades having to do it instead. 〈その場合 仲間が実行する それを理解しろと言われた〉
28:44 That combination of, 〈こういうことだ〉
28:47 "It has to be done, the police battalion has to do the job" 〈“大隊がやるしかない これは任務だ”〉
28:51 and, "If you're weak, you can refuse, but it's at the expense of your comrades." 〈“弱者は断ってもいい だが仲間が犠牲になる”〉
28:56 That combination creates the pressure 〈かなりの圧力だ〉
28:59 which led to most of them taking part in the shootings. 〈ほとんどの者は 銃撃に参加した〉
29:34 [narrator] Only a few policemen refuse to carry out the order to kill. 殺害命令を 拒否する警官は少なかった

29:58 They were called names: bastard, dirty rat, sissy and so on. 〈“ろくでなし 嫌なヤツ 臆病者”などとは呼ばれた〉
30:05 Those men were not at home, 〈彼らは家に帰らない〉
30:08 they didn't go back to their families at the end of the day. 〈一日の終わりに 家族の元に戻らない〉

30:24 You need to be very self-assured to be able to endure that. 〈耐えるには 余程自分に自信がなければ〉

30:57 [Browning] What's most on their mind, what's driving them? I don't think they're obsessed with Jews. 彼らがユダヤ人に 夢中なんてことはない
31:03 They're more motivated about-- 彼らの動機は…

31:10 I think they're very much obsessed with themselves, with how they're going to get through this. 事態をどう乗り越えるかが 彼らの関心事だ
31:15 [narrator] Captain Wolfgang Hoffmann believes he can take the pressure, ホフマン大尉には 圧力に打ち勝つ自信があった
31:21 but he has a problem. だが問題が生じた
31:23 [Browning] One of the captains develops a psychosomatic illness. 心因性の病気を発症する 指揮官もいた
31:29 He gets sick every time his company is supposed to carry out a killing action. 殺人の任務の日にはいつも 症状が悪化し
31:33 And so, he is in bed with terrible stomach cramps and can't even get out of bed. ひどい腹痛でベッドから 出られなくなった
31:37 And he has to have the killing action led by his subordinate. そして部下が 殺人の任務を執行
31:41 He wanted to be a killer, but his body broke down. 殺人を行いたくても 体が許さなかった
31:45 And the men, of course, thought this was terribly cowardly. 隊員たちは 彼を臆病者だと言い

31:51 [narrator] Things are very different for Captain Julius Wohlauf. ヴォーラウフ大尉は違った
31:55 He is ambitious, wants to carve out a career and excel at his job. 野心的で キャリアを築きたいタイプだ
32:00 And he's in love. それに恋をしていた
32:04 Wohlauf had married in Hamburg in June, shortly before the first massacre. ヴォーラウフは最初の虐殺の 直前に結婚をした
32:10 As an officer, he is allowed to take his wife to Poland, to the area of operations. 上官として妻を作戦地域へ 同行することが許された
32:16 He wants to make up for his missed honeymoon. 新婚旅行の代わりだ
32:26 [Browning] Wohlauf brings his pregnant bride on a ghetto clearing. ゲットーの浄化にも 妊娠中の妻を連れて行った
32:32 The most horrible ghetto clearing of the entire operation in virtually all the men's testimony 証言によるとそれは 最もひどい浄化作戦だった
32:38 was when they took 11,000 Jews from Miedzyrzec, １万1000人のユダヤ人を 移送した時だ
32:43 shot a thousand of them just in the ghetto clearing actions-- ゲットーから出す際 1000人を射殺し
32:45 the streets were just lined with dead bodies-- 道は死体でいっぱいだった
